isis.stitle: FRONT DRIVE AXLE WHEEL ENDS: ROCKWELL - DISASSEMBLY - STEERING KNUCKLE

note.para: On larger axles above 16,000 lb. GAWR, the steering knuckle MUST be disassembled before the steering universal joint can be removed. On axles below 16,000 lb GAWR, the steering universal joint can be removed without disassembling the steering knuckle.
On ALL models, the steering arm and tie rod assemblies can be serviced without removing the steering knuckle from the housing.

svcsubproc.title: STEERING KNUCKLE AND TIE ROD ARM

step1.para: Remove the steering arm ball cotter pin and nut to disconnect the steering linkage from the steering arm. It is not necessary to remove the steering arm from the knuckle at this time.
Remove the tie rod end cotter pin and nut to disassemble the tie rod assembly from the knuckle arm ( Figure 8).

figure.caption: Figure 8. Typical Tie Rod End Assembly

step1.para: Push the stud for the tie rod end through the knuckle arm. If necessary, use a soft mallet to hit the stud through the knuckle arm.

note.para: It is not necessary to remove both tie rod ends unless both knuckle assemblies are being serviced at the same time.

step1.para: Remove the four capscrews from the upper knuckle cap.
Lift the upper knuckle cap assembly from the bore. Keep the shims together for use at reassembly ( Figure 9).
After both the upper and lower knuckle cap assemblies are removed, pull the steering knuckle from the housing. Leave the universal joint in the housing.

Depending on which design of knuckle you are working on, the bushings or bearing cups will remain in the sockets of the housing. Inspect the upper and lower bushings or bearing cups while they are still in the sockets for wear or damage ( Figure 10).

figure.caption: Figure 10. Bushing or Bearing Cup and Knuckle Assembly

step1.para: If necessary, remove the bushings or bearing cups and the socket plugs from the upper and lower sockets in the housing. Use a sleeve with approximately the same diameter as the inside bore of the socket.

step3.para: Grind off the four tack welds that hold the socket plugs to the housing.

caution.para: Grind the tack welds carefully so that the bore is not damaged. No other grinding is permitted in the bore.

step3.para: Remove the plug by driving it toward the center of the socket with a drift that fits inside the bushing ( Figure 11).
Drive the bushing toward the outside of the socket using a sleeve that is slightly smaller than the socket bore ( Figure 12).
Clean all grease and dirt from the bores before reassembly.
There are no tack welds to remove.
Drive the plugs and bushings or bearing cups toward the outside of the sockets with the sleeve against the plugs.

para.emph: International vehicles will have the following knuckle designs:

step1.para: (Code 02191) Full Bushing King Pin Design ( Figure 13)
(Codes 02ERD, 02ERE, 02ERG) Full Bearing King Pin Design ( Figure 14).

svcsubproc.para: The correct disassembly procedure for each design of knuckle follows:

step1.para: Disassemble the upper knuckle cap. Inspect the oil seal on the upper knuckle cap for wear or damage. Replace a worn or damaged oil seal at reassembly.
Disassemble the lower knuckle cap. Inspect the oil seal for wear or damage. Replace a worn or damaged oil seal at reassembly.
Remove the thrust washer and retaining pin, if necessary, from the lower socket. Inspect the thrust washer for wear or damage and replace it, if necessary, at reassembly.
Disassemble the upper knuckle cap. Inspect the oil seal and bearing cone on the upper knuckle cap for wear or damage. Replace all parts that are worn or damaged.
Disassemble the lower knuckle cap. Inspect the oil seal and bearing cone for wear or damage. Replace all parts that are worn or damaged.
